{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3546595,"name":null,"username":"A_human","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/a_human/{size}/186621_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-03T21:54:51.285Z","cooked":"

I was wondering if any teams are using the the Arducam OV9281 camera for PhotonVision and would be willing to share their camera configurations. Any resolution will work. I’m happy to answer questions if needed. Sorry for the wall of text below.

How do I find my camera calibration?
  1. Go to photonvision.local:[port number] or whatever your team uses.
  2. Click on the camera tab on the left.
  3. Select the camera from the list of available cameras. Its Arducam Model should be OV9281.
  4. Under the Camera Calibration section, there are a whole bunch of camera calibrations with resolutions next to them. Click on the info icon on the right.
  5. This will show a popup with with the calibration details. Simply click on export to export it.
  6. Upload the file to Chief Delphi.

Just to be clear, I’m mainly asking because I don’t entirely trust any calibrations that we currently have for other cameras (There is one camera that we are currently using, and it’s a fish-eye meant for driving). If other teams have calibrations that they know work, then at least I know that that’s not going to be a potential point of failure, and it’s one less thing that I have to worry about when trying to get things accurate. It also means that I have something to compare future calibrations that our team makes to.

I believe the camera calibration is specfic to your cameras even if they are the same model due to focus and small imperfections in the lens “The calibration data collected during calibration is specific to each physical camera, as well as each individual resolution.” from photonvision website. To alleivate any worries about your calibration photonvison has two great fit factors to check. First is the FOV which should be + or - 10 from the manufactuer spec and the mean pixel error which should be less than 1. You can also take more calibration images as this helps cover any blind spots ideally if you have time you can take up to 50 images.

Currently, I think that for my situation I would rather have a really good calibration that’s slightly wrong for the camera, than a bad calibration for the right camera.

I.","username":"haarcz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/haarcz/{size}/213605_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-04T00:15:14.064Z","cooked":"

I would reccomend GitHub - TheHolyCows/cowlibration-camera by Holy Cows. We tried it this year with our cameras and makes the process of calibration and reducing the mean pixel error a lot easier by only requiring a 30-40 second long video. The only issue is output file is not supported by photonvision so you should do a mock calibration using PV first and edit the .json with correct data.
